Good Maria, let this fellow be looked to. Where's
my cousin Toby? Let some of my people have a
special care of him: I would not have him miscarry for
the half of my dowry.

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: O, ho! do you come near me now? no worse man than
Sir Toby to look to me! This concurs directly
with the letter: she sends him on purpose, that
I may appear stubborn to him; for she incites me
to that in the letter. “Cast thy humble slough,”
says she: “be opposite with a kinsman, surly with
servants; let thy tongue tang with arguments of
state; put thyself into the trick of singularity;”
and consequently sets down the manner how; as,
a sad face, a reverend carriage, a slow tongue,
in the habit of some sir of note, and so forth.
I have limed her; but it is Jove's doing, and
Jove make me thankful! And when she went away
now, “Let this fellow be looked to:” fellow! not
Malvolio, nor after my degree, but fellow. Why,
every thing adheres together, that no dram of a
scruple, no scruple of a scruple, no obstacle,
no incredulous or unsafe circumstance — What can
be said? Nothing that can be can come between me
and the full prospect of my hopes. Well, Jove,
not I, is the doer of this, and he is to be thanked.
sp.stage: Re-enter MARIA, with SIR TOBY and FABIAN.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: Which way is he, in the name of sanctity? If all
the devils of hell be drawn in little, and Legion
himself possessed him, yet I'll speak to him.

sp.speaker: Fabian
sp.ab: Here he is, here he is. How is't with you, sir? how
is't with you, man?

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: Go off; I discard you: let me enjoy my private: go
off.

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.ab: Lo, how hollow the fiend speaks within him! did
not I tell you? Sir Toby, my lady prays you to have a
care of him.

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: Ah, ha! does she so?

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: Go to, go to; peace, peace; we must deal gently
with him: let me alone. How do you, Malvolio?
how is't with you? What, man! defy the devil:
consider, he's an enemy to mankind.

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: Do you know what you say?

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.ab: La you, an you speak ill of the devil, how he takes it
at heart! Pray God, he be not bewitched!

sp.speaker: Fabian
sp.ab: Carry his water to the wise woman.

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.ab: Marry, and it shall be done to-morrow morning,
if I live. My lady would not lose him for more than
I'll say.

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: How now, mistress!

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.ab: O Lord!

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: Prithee, hold thy peace; this is not the way: do you
not see you move him? let me alone with him.

sp.speaker: Fabian
sp.ab: No way but gentleness; gently, gently: the fiend is
rough, and will not be roughly used.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: Why, how now, my bawcock! how dost thou, chuck?

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: Ay, Biddy, come with me. What, man! 'tis not for
gravity to play at cherry-pit with Satan: hang him,
foul collier!

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.ab: Get him to say his prayers, good Sir Toby, get him to
pray.

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: My prayers, minx!

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.ab: No, I warrant you, he will not hear of godliness.

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: Go, hang yourselves all! you are idle shallow
things: I am not of your element: you shall know more
hereafter.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Fabian
sp.ab: If this were played upon a stage now, I could condemn
it as an improbable fiction.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: His very genius hath taken the infection of the
device, man.

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.ab: Nay, pursue him now, lest the device take air and
taint.

sp.speaker: Fabian
sp.ab: Why, we shall make him mad indeed.

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.ab: The house will be the quieter.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: Come, we'll have him in a dark room and bound.
My niece is already in the belief that he's mad:
we may carry it thus, for our pleasure and his
penance, till our very pastime, tired out of
breath, prompt us to have mercy on him: at which
time we will bring the device to the bar and
crown thee for a finder of madmen. But see, but see.

sp.speaker: Fabian
sp.ab: More matter for a May morning.

sp.speaker: Sir Andrew
sp.ab: Here's the challenge, read it: I warrant there's
vinegar and pepper in't.

sp.speaker: Fabian
sp.ab: Is't so saucy?

sp.speaker: Sir Andrew
sp.ab: Ay, is't, I warrant him: do but read.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: Give me.
“Youth, whatsoever thou art, thou art but a scurvy
fellow.”

sp.speaker: Fabian
sp.ab: Good, and valiant.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: “Wonder not, nor admire not in thy mind, why I
do call thee so, for I will show thee no reason
for't.”

sp.speaker: Fabian
sp.ab: A good note; that keeps you from the blow of the law.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: “Thou comest to the lady Olivia, and in my sight
she uses thee kindly: but thou liest in thy
throat; that is not the matter I challenge thee for.”

sp.speaker: Fabian
sp.ab: Very brief, and to exceeding good sense — less.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: “I will waylay thee going home; where if it be thy
chance to kill me,”

sp.speaker: Fabian
sp.ab: Good.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: “Thou kill'st me like a rogue and a villain.”

sp.speaker: Fabian
sp.ab: Still you keep o' the windy side of the law: good.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: “Fare thee well; and God have mercy upon one of
our souls! He may have mercy upon mine; but my
hope is better, and so look to thyself. Thy
friend, as thou usest him, and thy sworn enemy,
ANDREW AGUECHEEK” If this letter move him not, his
legs cannot: I'll give't him.

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.ab: You may have very fit occasion for't: he is now
in some commerce with my lady, and will by and by
depart.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: Go, Sir Andrew: scout me for him at the corner
of the orchard like a bum-baily: so soon as ever
thou seest him, draw; and, as thou draw'st, swear
horrible; for it comes to pass oft that a terrible
oath, with a swaggering accent sharply twanged
off, gives manhood more approbation than ever proof
itself would have earned him. Away!

sp.speaker: Sir Andrew
sp.ab: Nay, let me alone for swearing.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: Now will not I deliver his letter: for the
behaviour of the young gentleman gives him out
to be of good capacity and breeding; his employment
between his lord and my niece confirms no less:
therefore this letter, being so excellently
ignorant, will breed no terror in the youth: he
will find it comes from a clotpoll. But, sir, I
will deliver his challenge by word of mouth; set
upon Aguecheek a notable report of valour; and
drive the gentleman, as I know his youth will
aptly receive it, into a most hideous opinion of
his rage, skill, fury and impetuosity. This will
so fright them both that they will kill one another by
the look, like cockatrices.

sp.speaker: Fabian
sp.ab: Here he comes with your niece: give them way till he
take leave, and presently after him.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: I will meditate the while upon some horrid message for
a challenge.
sp.stage: Exeunt Sir Toby, Fabian, and Maria.

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: I have said too much unto a heart of stone
And laid mine honour too unchary on't:
There's something in me that reproves my fault;
But such a headstrong potent fault it is,
That it but mocks reproof.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.l: With the same “haviour that your passion bears
Goes on my master's grief.

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: Here, wear this jewel for me, 'tis my picture;
Refuse it not; it hath no tongue to vex you;
And I beseech you come again to-morrow.
What shall you ask of me that I'll deny,
That honour saved may upon asking give?

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.l: Nothing but this; your true love for my master.

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: How with mine honour may I give him that
Which I have given to you?

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.l: I will acquit you.

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: Well, come again to-morrow: fare thee well:
A fiend like thee might bear my soul to hell. Exit. Re-enter SIR TOBY and FABIAN.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: Gentleman, God save thee.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.ab: And you, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: That defence thou hast, betake thee to't: of what
nature the wrongs are thou hast done him, I know
not; but thy intercepter, full of despite, bloody
as the hunter, attends thee at the orchard-end:
dismount thy tuck, be yare in thy preparation, for thy
assailant is quick, skilful and deadly.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.ab: You mistake, sir; I am sure no man hath any
quarrel to me: my remembrance is very free and clear
from any image of offence done to any man.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: You'll find it otherwise, I assure you: therefore,
if you hold your life at any price, betake you
to your guard; for your opposite hath in him what
youth, strength, skill and wrath can furnish man
withal.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.ab: I pray you, sir, what is he?

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: He is knight, dubbed with unhatched rapier and
on carpet consideration; but he is a devil in
private brawl: souls and bodies hath he divorced
three; and his incensement at this moment is so
implacable, that satisfaction can be none but by
pangs of death and sepulchre. Hob, nob, is his word;
give't or take't.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.ab: I will return again into the house and desire
some conduct of the lady. I am no fighter. I have
heard of some kind of men that put quarrels
purposely on others, to taste their valour: belike
this is a man of that quirk.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: Sir, no; his indignation derives itself out of
a very competent injury: therefore, get you on
and give him his desire. Back you shall not to
the house, unless you undertake that with me
which with as much safety you might answer him:
therefore, on, or strip your sword stark naked;
for meddle you must, that's certain, or forswear to
wear iron about you.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.ab: This is as uncivil as strange. I beseech you, do
me this courteous office, as to know of the knight
what my offence to him is: it is something of my
negligence, nothing of my purpose.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: I will do so. Signior Fabian, stay you by this
gentleman till my return.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.ab: Pray you, sir, do you know of this matter?

sp.speaker: Fabian
sp.ab: I know the knight is incensed against you, even
to a mortal arbitrement; but nothing of the
circumstance more.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.ab: I beseech you, what manner of man is he?

sp.speaker: Fabian
sp.ab: Nothing of that wonderful promise, to read him
by his form, as you are like to find him in the
proof of his valour. He is, indeed, sir, the most
skilful, bloody and fatal opposite that you could
possibly have found in any part of Illyria. Will
you walk towards him? I will make your peace with him
if I can.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.ab: I shall be much bound to you for't: I am one that
had rather go with sir priest than sir knight: I care
not who knows so much of my mettle.
sp.stage: Re-enter SIR TOBY, with SIR ANDREW.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: Why, man, he's a very devil; I have not seen such
a firago. I had a pass with him, rapier, scabbard
and all, and he gives me the stuck-in with such
a mortal motion, that it is inevitable; and on
the answer, he pays you as surely as your feet
hits the ground they step on. They say he has been
fencer to the Sophy.

sp.speaker: Sir Andrew
sp.ab: Pox on't, I'll not meddle with him.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: Ay, but he will not now be pacified: Fabian can scarce
hold him yonder.

sp.speaker: Sir Andrew
sp.ab: Plague on't, an I thought he had been valiant
and so cunning in fence, I'ld have seen him damned
ere I'ld have challenged him. Let him let the
matter slip, and I'll give him my horse, grey Capilet.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: I'll make the motion: stand here, make a good
show on't: this shall end without the perdition
of souls.
Marry, I'll ride your horse as well as I ride
you.
I have his horse to take up the quarrel: I have
persuaded him the youth's a devil.

sp.speaker: Fabian
sp.ab: He is as horribly conceited of him; and pants and
looks pale, as if a bear were at his heels.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: There's no remedy, sir; he will fight with you
for's oath sake: marry, he hath better bethought
him of his quarrel, and he finds that now scarce
to be worth talking of: therefore draw, for the
supportance of his vow; he protests he will not hurt
you.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.ab: Pray God defend me! A little thing would make me tell
them how much I lack of a man.

sp.speaker: Fabian
sp.ab: Give ground, if you see him furious.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: Come, Sir Andrew, there's no remedy; the gentleman
will, for his honour's sake, have one bout with
you; he cannot by the duello avoid it: but he
has promised me, as he is a gentleman and a soldier,
he will not hurt you. Come on; to't.

sp.speaker: Sir Andrew
sp.ab: Pray God, he keep his oath!

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.l: I do assure you, 'tis against my will. They draw. Enter ANTONIO.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Put up your sword. If this young gentleman
Have done offence, I take the fault on me:
If you offend him, I for him defy you.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: You, sir! why, what are you?

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: One, sir, that for his love dares yet do more
Than you have heard him brag to you he will.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: Nay, if you be an undertaker, I am for you.

sp.speaker: Fabian
sp.ab: O good Sir Toby, hold! here come the officers.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: I'll be with you anon.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.ab: Pray, sir, put your sword up, if you please.

sp.speaker: Sir Andrew
sp.ab: Marry, will I, sir; and, for that I promised you,
I'll be as good as my word: he will bear you easily
and reins well.

sp.speaker: First Officer
sp.ab: This is the man; do thy office.

sp.speaker: Second Officer
sp.ab: Antonio, I arrest thee at the suit of Count Orsino.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.ab: You do mistake me, sir.

sp.speaker: First Officer
sp.l: No, sir, no jot; I know your favour well,
Though now you have no sea-cap on your head.
Take him away: he knows I know him well.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: I must obey. To Vio. This comes with seeking you:
But there's no remedy; I shall answer it.
What will you do, now my necessity
Makes me to ask you for my purse? It grieves me
Much more for what I cannot do for you
Than what befalls myself. You stand amazed;
But be of comfort.

sp.speaker: Second Officer
sp.ab: Come, sir, away.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.ab: I must entreat of you some of that money.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.l: What money, sir?
For the fair kindness you have showed me here,
And, part, being prompted by your present trouble,
Out of my lean and low ability
I'll lend you something: my having is not much;
I'll make division of my present with you:
Hold, there's half my coffer.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Will you deny me now?
Is't possible that my deserts to you
Can lack persuasion? Do not tempt my misery,
Lest that it make me so unsound a man
As to upbraid you with those kindnesses
That I have done for you.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.l: I know of none;
Nor know I you by voice or any feature:
I hate ingratitude more in a man
Than lying, vainness, babbling, drunkenness,
Or any taint of vice whose strong corruption
Inhabits our frail blood.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: O heavens themselves!

sp.speaker: Second Officer
sp.l: Come, sir, I pray you, go.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Let me speak a little. This youth that you see here
I snatched one half out of the jaws of death,
Relieved him with such sanctity of love,
And to his image, which methought did promise
Most venerable worth, did I devotion.

sp.speaker: First Officer
sp.l: What's that to us? The time goes by: away!

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: But O how vile an idol proves this god
Thou hast, Sebastian, done good feature shame.
In nature there's no blemish but the mind;
None can be called deformed but the unkind:
Virtue is beauty, but the beauteous evil
Are empty trunks o'erflourished by the devil.

sp.speaker: First Officer
sp.l: The man grows mad: away with him! Come, come, sir.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Lead me on. Exit with Officers.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.l: Methinks his words do from such passion fly,
That he believes himself: so do not I.
Prove true, imagination, O, prove true,
That I, dear brother, be now ta'en for you!

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: Come hither, knight; come hither, Fabian: we'll
whisper o'er a couplet or two of most sage saws.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.l: He named Sebastian: I my brother know
Yet living in my glass; even such and so
In favour was my brother, and he went
Still in this fashion, colour, ornament,
For him I imitate: O, if it prove,
Tempests are kind and salt waves fresh in love. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: A very dishonest paltry boy, and more a coward
than a hare: his dishonesty appears in leaving
his friend here in necessity and denying him; and for
his cowardship, ask Fabian.

sp.speaker: Fabian
sp.ab: A coward, a most devout coward, religious in it.

sp.speaker: Sir Andrew
sp.ab: 'Slid, I'll after him again and beat him.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: Do; cuff him soundly, but never draw thy sword.

sp.speaker: Sir Andrew
sp.ab: An I do not,

sp.speaker: Fabian
sp.ab: Come, let's see the event.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: I dare lay any money 'twill be nothing yet.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Will you make me believe that I am not sent for you?

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Go to, go to, thou art a foolish fellow:
Let me be clear of thee.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Well held out, i' faith! No, I do not know you;
nor I am not sent to you by my lady, to bid you
come speak with her; nor your name is not Master
Cesario; nor this is not my nose neither. Nothing that
is so is so.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: I prithee, vent thy folly somewhere else:
Thou know'st not me.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Vent my folly; he has heard that word of some
great man and now applies it to a fool. Vent my
folly! I am afraid this great lubber, the world,
will prove a cockney. I prithee now, ungird thy
strangeness and tell me what I shall vent to my lady:
shall I vent to her that thou art coming?

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: I prithee, foolish Greek, depart from me:
There's money for thee: if you tarry longer,
I shall give worse payment.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: By my troth, thou hast an open hand. These wise
men that give fools money get themselves a good report
after fourteen years' purchase.
sp.stage: Enter SIR ANDREW, SIR TOBY, and FABIAN.

sp.speaker: Sir Andrew
sp.ab: Now, sir, have I met you again? there's for you.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Why, there's for thee, and there, and there.
Are all the people mad?

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: Hold, sir, or I'll throw your dagger o'er the house.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: This will I tell my lady straight: I would not be in
some of your coats for twopence.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: Come on, sir; hold.

sp.speaker: Sir Andrew
sp.ab: Nay, let him alone: I'll go another way to work
with him; I'll have an action of battery against
him, if there be any law in Illyria: though I struck
him first, yet it's no matter for that.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.ab: Let go thy hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: Come, sir, I will not let you go. Come, my young
soldier, put up your iron: you are well fleshed; come
on.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: I will be free from thee. What wouldst thou now?
If thou darest tempt me further, draw thy sword.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: What, what? Nay, then I must have an ounce or two of
this malapert blood from you.

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: Hold, Toby; on thy life I charge thee, hold!

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: Madam!

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: Will it be ever thus? Ungracious wretch,
Fit for the mountains and the barbarous caves,
Where manners ne'er were preached! out of my sight!
Be not offended, dear Cesario.
Rudesby, be gone! Exeunt Sir Toby, Sir Andrew, and Fabian. I prithee, gentle friend,
Let thy fair wisdom, not thy passion, sway
In this uncivil and unjust extent
Against thy peace. Go with me to my house,
And hear thou there how many fruitless pranks
This ruffian hath botched up, that thou thereby
Mayst smile at this: thou shalt not choose but go:
Do not deny. Beshrew his soul for me,
He started one poor heart of mine in thee.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: What relish is in this? how runs the stream?
Or I am mad, or else this is a dream:
Let fancy still my sense in Lethe steep;
If it be thus to dream, still let me sleep!

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: Nay, come, I prithee; would thou'ldst be ruled by me!

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Madam, I will.

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: O, say so, and so be! Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.ab: Nay, I prithee, put on this gown and this beard;
make him believe thou art Sir Topas the curate: do it
quickly; I'll call Sir Toby the whilst.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Well, I'll put it on, and I will dissemble myself
in't; and I would I were the first that ever
dissembled in such a gown. I am not tall enough
to become the function well, nor lean enough to
be thought a good student; but to be said an
honest man and a good housekeeper goes as fairly
as to say a careful man and a great scholar. The
competitors enter.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: Jove bless thee, master Parson.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Bonos dies, Sir Toby: for, as the old hermit of
Prague, that never saw pen and ink, very wittily
said to a niece of King Gorboduc, “That that is
is;” so I, being Master Parson, am master Parson; for,
what is “that” but “that,” and “is” but “is”?

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: To him, Sir Topas.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: What, ho, I say! peace in this prison!

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: The knave counterfeits well; a good knave.

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: Who calls there?

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Sir Topas the curate, who comes to visit Malvolio the
lunatic.

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: Sir Topas, Sir Topas, good Sir Topas, go to my lady.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Out, hyperbolical fiend! how vexest thou this man!
talkest thou nothing but of ladies?

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: Well said, master Parson.

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: Sir Topas, never was man thus wronged: good Sir
Topas, do not think I am mad: they have laid me here
in hideous darkness.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Fie, thou dishonest Satan! I call thee by the
most modest terms; for I am one of those gentle
ones that will use the devil himself with courtesy:
sayest thou that house is dark?

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: As hell, Sir Topas.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Why, it hath bay windows transparent as barricadoes,
and the clerestories toward the south north are
as lustrous as ebony; and yet complainest thou of
obstruction?

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: I am not mad, Sir Topas: I say to you, this house is
dark.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Madman, thou errest: I say, there is no darkness
but ignorance; in which thou art more puzzled than the
Egyptians in their fog.

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: I say, this house is as dark as ignorance, though
ignorance were as dark as hell; and I say, there
was never man thus abused. I am no more mad than
you are: make the trial of it in any constant
question.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: What is the opinion of Pythagoras concerning
wild-fowl?

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: That the soul of our grandam might happily inhabit a
bird.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: What thinkest thou of his opinion?

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: I think nobly of the soul, and no way approve his
opinion.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Fare thee well. Remain thou still in darkness:
thou shalt hold the opinion of Pythagoras ere I
will allow of thy wits, and fear to kill a
woodcock, lest thou dispossess the soul of thy
grandam. Fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: Sir Topas, Sir Topas!

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: My most exquisite Sir Topas!

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Nay, I am for all waters.

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.ab: Thou mightst have done this without thy beard and
gown: he sees thee not.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: To him in thine own voice, and bring me word how
thou find'st him: I would we were well rid of
this knavery. If he may be conveniently delivered,
I would he were, for I am now so far in offence
with my niece that I cannot pursue with any safety
this sport to the upshot. Come by and by to my
chamber.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.l: “Hey, Robin, jolly Robin,
Tell me how thy lady does.”

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: Fool!

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.l: “My lady is unkind, perdy.”

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: Fool!

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.l: “Alas, why is she so?”

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: Fool, I say!

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.l: “She loves another”
sp.ab: Who calls, ha?

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: Good fool, as ever thou wilt deserve well at my
hand, help me to a candle, and pen, ink and paper:
as I am a gentleman, I will live to be thankful to
thee for't.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Master Malvolio?

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: Ay, good fool.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Alas, sir, how fell you besides your five wits?

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: Fool, there was never man so notoriously abused: I am
as well in my wits, fool, as thou art.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: But as well? then you are mad indeed, if you be no
better in your wits than a fool.

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: They have here propertied me; keep me in darkness,
send ministers to me, asses, and do all they can to
face me out of my wits.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Advise you what you say; the minister is here.
Malvolio, Malvolio, thy wits the heavens restore!
endeavour thyself to sleep, and leave thy vain bibble
babble.

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: Sir Topas!

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Maintain no words with him, good fellow. Who, I,
sir? not I, sir. God buy you, good Sir Topas. Marry,
amen. I will, sir, I will.

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: Fool, fool, fool, I say!

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Alas, sir, be patient. What say you sir? I am shent
for speaking to you.

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: Good fool, help me to some light and some paper:
I tell thee, I am as well in my wits as any man in
Illyria.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Well-a-day that you were, sir!

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: By this hand, I am. Good fool, some ink, paper
and light; and convey what I will set down to my
lady: it shall advantage thee more than ever the
bearing of letter did.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: I will help you to't. But tell me true, are you not
mad indeed? or do you but counterfeit?

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: Believe me, I am not; I tell thee true.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Nay, I'll ne'er believe a madman till I see his
brains. I will fetch you light and paper and ink.

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: Fool, I'll requite it in the highest degree: I
prithee, be gone.

lg.l: I am gone, sir,
And anon, sir,
I'll be with you again,
In a trice,
Like to the old Vice,
Your need to sustain;
Who, with dagger of lath.
In his rage and his wrath,
Cries, ah, ha! to the devil:
Like a mad lad,
Pare thy nails, dad;
Adieu, goodman devil.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: This is the air; that is the glorious sun;
This pearl she gave me, I do feel't and see't;
And though 'tis wonder that enwraps me thus,
Yet 'tis not madness. Where's Antonio, then?
I could not find him at the Elephant:
Yet there he was; and there I found this credit,
That he did range the town to seek me out.
His counsel now might do me golden service;
For though my soul disputes well with my sense,
That this may be some error, but no madness,
Yet doth this accident and flood of fortune
So far exceed all instance, all discourse,
That I am ready to distrust mine eyes
And wrangle with my reason that persuades me
To any other trust but that I am mad
Or else the lady's mad; yet, if 'twere so,
She could not sway her house, command her followers,
Take and give back affairs and their dispatch
With such a smooth, discreet and stable bearing
As I perceive she does: there's something in't
That is deceivable. But here the lady comes. Enter OLIVIA and Priest.

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: Blame not this haste of mine. If you mean well,
Now go with me and with this holy man
Into the chantry by: there, before him,
And underneath that consecrated roof,
Plight me the full assurance of your faith;
That my most jealous and too doubtful soul
May live at peace. He shall conceal it
Whiles you are willing it shall come to note,
What time we will our celebration keep
According to my birth. What do you say?

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: I'll follow this good man, and go with you;
And, having sworn truth, ever will be true.

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: Then lead the way, good father; and heavens so shine,
That they may fairly note this act of mine! Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fabian
sp.ab: Now, as thou lovest me, let me see his letter.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Good Master Fabian, grant me another request.

sp.speaker: Fabian
sp.ab: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Do not desire to see this letter.

sp.speaker: Fabian
sp.ab: This is, to give a dog, and in recompense desire my
dog again.
sp.stage: Enter DUKE, VIOLA, CURIO, and Lords.

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.ab: Belong you to the Lady Olivia, friends?

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Ay, sir; we are some of her trappings.

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.ab: I know thee well: how dost thou, my good fellow?

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Truly, sir, the better for my foes and the worse for
my friends.

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.ab: Just the contrary; the better for thy friends.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: No, sir, the worse.

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.ab: How can that be?

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Marry, sir, they praise me and make an ass of
me; now my foes tell me plainly I am an ass: so
that by my foes, sir, I profit in the knowledge
of myself, and by my friends I am abused: so
that, conclusions to be as kisses, if your four
negatives make your two affirmatives, why then,
the worse for my friends and the better for my foes.

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.ab: Why, this is excellent.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: By my troth, sir, no; though it please you to be one
of my friends.

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.ab: Thou shalt not be the worse for me: there's gold.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: But that it would be double-dealing, sir, I would you
could make it another.

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.ab: O, you give me ill counsel.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Put your grace in your pocket, sir, for this once, and
let your flesh and blood obey it.

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.ab: Well, I will be so much a sinner, to be a
double-dealer: there's another.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Primo, secundo, tertio, is a good play; and the
old saying is, the third pays for all: the triplex,
sir, is a good tripping measure; or the bells of
Saint Bennet, sir, may put you in mind; one, two,
three.

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.ab: You can fool no more money out of me at this
throw: if you will let your lady know I am here
to speak with her, and bring her along with you, it
may awake my bounty further.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Marry, sir, lullaby to your bounty till I come
again. I go, sir; but I would not have you to
think that my desire of having is the sin of
covetousness: but, as you say, sir, let your bounty
take a nap, I will awake it anon.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.l: Here comes the man, sir, that did rescue me. Enter ANTONIO and Officers.

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.l: That face of his I do remember well;
Yet, when I saw it last, it was besmeared
As black as Vulcan in the smoke of war:
A baubling vessel was he captain of,
For shallow draught and bulk unprizable;
With which such scathful grapple did he make
With the most noble bottom of our fleet,
That very envy and the tongue of loss
Cried fame and honour on him. What's the matter?

sp.speaker: First Officer
sp.l: Orsino, this is that Antonio
That took the Phoenix and her fraught from Candy;
And this is he that did the Tiger board,
When your young nephew Titus lost his leg:
Here in the streets, desperate of shame and state,
In private brabble did we apprehend him

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.l: He did me kindness, sir, drew on my side;
But in conclusion put strange speech upon me:
I know not what 'twas but distraction.

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.l: Notable pirate! thou salt-water thief!
What foolish boldness brought thee to their mercies,
Whom thou, in terms so bloody and so dear,
Hast made thine enemies?

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Orsino, noble sir,
Be pleased that I shake off these names you give me:
Antonio never yet was thief or pirate,
Though I confess, on base and ground enough,
Orsino's enemy. A witchcraft drew me hither:
That most ingrateful boy there by your side
From the rude sea's enraged and foamy mouth
Did I redeem; a wrack past hope he was:
His life I gave him and did thereto add
My love, without retention or restraint,
All his in dedication; for his sake
Did I expose myself, pure for his love,
Into the danger of this adverse town;
Drew to defend him when he was beset:
Where being apprehended, his false cunning,
Not meaning to partake with me in danger,
Taught him to face me out of his acquaintance,
And grew a twenty years removed thing
While one would wink; denied me mine own purse,
Which I had recommended to his use
Not half an hour before.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.l: How can this be?

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.l: When came he to this town?

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: to-day, my lord; and for three months before,
No interim, not a minute's vacancy,
Both day and night did we keep company. Enter OLIVIA and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.l: Here comes the countess: now heaven walks on earth.
But for thee, fellow; fellow, thy words are madness:
Three months this youth hath tended upon me;
But more of that anon. Take him aside.

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: What would my lord, but that he may not have,
Wherein Olivia may seem serviceable?
Cesario, you do not keep promise with me.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.l: Madam!

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.l: Gracious Olivia,

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: What do you say, Cesario? Good my lord,

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.l: My lord would speak; my duty hushes me.

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: If it be aught to the old tune, my lord,
It is as fat and fulsome to mine ear
As howling after music.

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.l: Still so cruel?

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: Still so constant, lord.

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.l: What, to perverseness? you uncivil lady,
To whose ingrate and unauspicious altars
My soul the faithfull'st offerings have breathed out
That e'er devotion tendered! What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: Even what it please my lord, that shall become him.

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.l: Why should I not, had I the heart to do it,
Like to the Egyptian thief at point of death,
Kill what I love? — a savage jealousy
That sometime savours nobly. But hear me this:
Since you to non-regardance cast my faith,
And that I partly know the instrument
That screws me from my true place in your favour,
Live you the marble-breasted tyrant still;
But this your minion, whom I know you love,
And whom, by heaven I swear, I tender dearly,
Him will I tear out of that cruel eye,
Where he sits crowned in his master's spite.
Come, boy, with me; my thoughts are ripe in mischief:
I'll sacrifice the lamb that I do love,
To spite a raven's heart within a dove.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.l: And I, most jocund, apt and willingly,
To do you rest, a thousand deaths would die.

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: Where goes Cesario?

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.l: After him I love
More than I love these eyes, more than my life,
More, by all mores, than e'er I shall love wife.
If I do feign, you witnesses above
Punish my life for tainting of my love!

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: Ay me, detested! how am I beguiled!

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.l: Who does beguile you? who does do you wrong?

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: Hast thou forgot thyself? is it so long?
Call forth the holy father.

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.l: Come, away!

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay.

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.l: Husband!

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: Ay, husband: can he that deny?

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.l: Her husband, sirrah!

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.l: No, my lord, not I.

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: Alas, it is the baseness of thy fear
That makes thee strangle thy propriety:
Fear not, Cesario; take thy fortunes up;
Be that thou know'st thou art, and then thou art
As great as that thou fear'st. Enter Priest. O, welcome, father!
Father, I charge thee, by thy reverence,
Here to unfold, though lately we intended
To keep in darkness what occasion now
Reveals before 'tis ripe, what thou dost know
Hath newly passed between this youth and me.

sp.speaker: Priests
sp.l: A contract of eternal bond of love,
Confirmed by mutual joinder of your hands,
Attested by the holy close of lips,
Strengthened by interchangement of your rings;
And all the ceremony of this compact
Sealed in my function, by my testimony:
Since when, my watch hath told me, toward my grave
I have travelled but two hours.”

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.l: O thou dissembling cub! what wilt thou be
When time hath sowed a grizzle on thy case?
Or will not else thy craft so quickly grow,
That thine own trip shall be thine overthrow?
Farewell, and take her; but direct thy feet
Where thou and I henceforth may never meet.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.l: My lord, I do protest

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: O, do not swear!
Hold little faith, though thou hast too much fear. Enter SIR ANDREW.

sp.speaker: Sir Andrew
sp.ab: For the love of God, a surgeon! Send one presently to
Sir Toby.

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.ab: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sir Andrew
sp.ab: He's broke my head across and has given Sir Toby
a bloody coxcomb too: for the love of God, your help!
I had rather than forty pound I were at home.

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.ab: Who has done this, Sir Andrew?

sp.speaker: Sir Andrew
sp.ab: The count's gentleman, one Cesario: we took him for a
coward, but he's the very devil incardinate.

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.ab: My gentleman, Cesario?

sp.speaker: Sir Andrew
sp.ab: 'Od's lifelings, here he is! You broke my head
for nothing; and that that I did, I was set on to do't
by Sir Toby.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.l: Why do you speak to me? I never hurt you:
You drew your sword upon me without cause;
But I bespake you fair, and hurt you not.

sp.speaker: Sir Andrew
sp.ab: If a bloody coxcomb be a hurt, you have hurt me:
I think you set nothing by a bloody coxcomb.
Here comes Sir Toby halting: you shall hear more:
but if he had not been in drink, he would have tickled
you othergates than he did.

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.l: How now, gentleman! how is't with you?

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: That's all one: he's hurt me, and there's the end
on't. Sot, didst see Dick surgeon, sot?

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: O, he's drunk, Sir Toby, an hour agone; his eyes were
set at eight i' the morning.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: Then he's a rogue, and a passy-measures pavane: I hate
a drunken rogue.

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.ab: Away with him! Who hath made this havoc with them?

sp.speaker: Sir Andrew
sp.ab: I'll help you, Sir Toby, because we'll be dressed
together.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.ab: Will you help? an ass-head and a coxcomb and a knave,
a thin-faced knave, a gull!

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: Get him to bed, and let his hurt be looked to. Exeunt Clown, Fabian, Sir Toby, and Sir Andrew. Enter SEBASTIAN.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: I am sorry, madam, I have hurt your kinsman;
But, had it been the brother of my blood,
I must have done no less with wit and safety.
You throw a strange regard upon me, and by that
I do perceive it hath offended you:
Pardon me, sweet one, even for the vows
We made each other but so late ago.

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.l: One face, one voice, one habit, and two persons,
A natural perspective, that is and is not!

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Antonio, O my dear Antonio!
How have the hours racked and tortured me,
Since I have lost thee!

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Sebastian are you?

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Fear'st thou that, Antonio?

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: How have you made division of yourself?
An apple, cleft in two, is not more twin
Than these two creatures. Which is Sebastian?

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: Most wonderful!

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Do I stand there? I never had a brother;
Nor can there be that deity in my nature,
Of here and every where. I had a sister,
Whom the blind waves and surges have devoured.
Of charity, what kin are you to me?
What countryman? what name? what parentage?

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.l: Of Messaline: Sebastian was my father;
Such a Sebastian was my brother too,
So went he suited to his watery tomb:
If spirits can assume both form and suit
You come to fright us.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: A spirit I am indeed;
But am in that dimension grossly clad
Which from the womb I did participate.
Were you a woman, as the rest goes even,
I should my tears let fall upon your cheek,
And say “Thrice welcome, drowned Viola!”

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.l: My father had a mole upon his brow,

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: And so had mine.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.l: And died that day when Viola from her birth
Had numbered thirteen years.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: O, that record is lively in my soul!
He finished indeed his mortal act
That day that made my sister thirteen years.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.l: If nothing lets to make us happy both
But this my masculine usurped attire,
Do not embrace me till each circumstance
Of place, time, fortune, do cohere and jump
That I am Viola: which to confirm,
I'll bring you to a captain in this town,
Where lie my maiden weeds; by whose gentle help
I was preserved to serve this noble count.
All the occurrence of my fortune since
Hath been between this lady and this lord.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: So comes it, lady, you have been mistook:
But nature to her bias drew in that.
You would have been contracted to a maid;
Nor are you therein, by my life, deceived,
You are betrothed both to a maid and man.

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.l: Be not amazed; right noble is his blood.
If this be so, as yet the glass seems true,
I shall have share in this most happy wrack. To Viola Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times
Thou never shouldst love woman like to me.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.l: And all those sayings will I over swear;
And all those swearings keep as true in soul
As doth that orbed continent the fire
That severs day from night.

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.l: Give me thy hand;
And let me see thee in thy woman's weeds.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.l: The captain that did bring me first on shore
Hath my maid's garments: he upon some action
Is now in durance, at Malvolio's suit,
A gentleman, and follower of my lady's.

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: He shall enlarge him: fetch Malvolio hither:
And yet, alas, now I remember me,
They say, poor gentleman, he's much distract. Re-enter CLOWN with a letter, and FABIAN.
A most extracting frenzy of mine own
From my remembrance clearly banished his.
How does he, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Truly, madam, he holds Beelzebub at the stave's
end as well as a man in his case may do: he's
here writ a letter to you; I should have given't
you to-day morning, but as a madman's epistles
are no gospels, so it skills not much when they are
delivered.

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.ab: Open't, and read it.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Look then to be well edified when the fool delivers
the madman.
“By the Lord, madam,”

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.ab: How now! art thou mad?

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: No, madam, I do but read madness: an your ladyship
will have it as it ought to be, you must allow Vox.

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.ab: Prithee, read i' thy right wits.

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: So I do, madonna; but to read his right wits is
to read thus: therefore perpend, my princess, and give
ear.

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.ab: Read it you, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Fabian
sp.ab: “By the Lord, madam, you wrong me, and the world
shall know it: though you have put me into darkness
and given your drunken cousin rule over me, yet
have I the benefit of my senses as well as your
ladyship. I have your own letter that induced me
to the semblance I put on; with the which I doubt
not but to do myself much right, or you much
shame. Think of me as you please. I leave my duty
a little unthought of and speak out of my injury. THE
MADLY-USED MALVOLIO.”

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.ab: Did he write this?

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Ay, madam.

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.l: This savours not much of distraction.

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: See him delivered, Fabian; bring him hither. Exit Fabian.
My lord, so please you, these things further thought on,
To think me as well a sister as a wife,
One day shall crown the alliance on't, so please you,
Here at my house and at my proper cost.

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.l: Madam, I am most apt to embrace your offer.
To Viola Your master quits you; and for your service done him,
So much against the mettle of your sex,
So far beneath your soft and tender breeding,
And since you called me master for so long,
Here is my hand: you shall from this time be
Your master's mistress.

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: A sister! you are she. Re-enter FABIAN, with MALVOLIO.

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.l: Is this the madman?

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: Ay, my lord, this same.
How now, Malvolio!

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.l: Madam, you have done me wrong,
Notorious wrong.

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: Have I, Malvolio? no.

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.l: Lady, you have. Pray you, peruse that letter.
You must not now deny it is your hand:
Write from it, if you can, in hand or phrase;
Or say 'tis not your seal, not your invention:
You can say none of this: well, grant it then
And tell me, in the modesty of honour,
Why you have given me such clear lights of favour,
Bade me come smiling and cross-gartered to you,
To put on yellow stockings and to frown
Upon Sir Toby and the lighter people;
And, acting this in an obedient hope,
Why have you suffered me to be imprisoned,
Kept in a dark house, visited by the priest,
And made the most notorious geck and gull
That e'er invention played on? tell me why.

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: Alas, Malvolio, this is not my writing,
Though, I confess, much like the character:
But out of question 'tis Maria's hand.
And now I do bethink me, it was she
First told me thou wast mad; then camest in smiling,
And in such forms which here were presupposed
Upon thee in the letter. Prithee, be content:
This practice hath most shrewdly passed upon thee;
But when we know the grounds and authors of it,
Thou shalt be both the plaintiff and the judge
Of thine own cause.

sp.speaker: Fabian
sp.l: Good madam, hear me speak,
And let no quarrel nor no brawl to come
Taint the condition of this present hour,
Which I have wondered at. In hope it shall not,
Most freely I confess, myself and Toby
Set this device against Malvolio here,
Upon some stubborn and uncourteous parts
We had conceived against him: Maria writ
The letter at Sir Toby's great importance;
In recompense whereof he hath married her.
How with a sportful malice it was followed,
May rather pluck on laughter than revenge;
If that the injuries be justly weighed
That have on both sides passed.

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: Alas, poor fool, how have they baffled thee!

sp.speaker: Feste
sp.ab: Why, “some are born great, some achieve greatness,
and some have greatness thrown upon them.” I was
one, sir, in this interlude; one Sir Topas, sir;
but that's all one. “By the Lord, fool, I am not
mad.” But do you remember? “Madam, why laugh you
at such a barren rascal? an you smile not, he's
gagged:” and thus the whirligig of time brings in his
revenges

sp.speaker: Malvolio
sp.ab: I'll be revenged on the whole pack of you.

sp.speaker: Olivia
sp.l: He hath been most notoriously abused.

sp.speaker: Orsino
sp.l: Pursue him, and entreat him to a peace:
He hath not told us of the captain yet:
When that is known and golden time convents,
A solemn combination shall be made
Of our dear souls. Meantime, sweet sister,
We will not part from hence. Cesario, come;
For so you shall be, while you are a man;
But when in other habits you are seen,
Orsino's mistress and his fancy's queen. Exeunt all, except Clown.

lg.l: When that I was and a little tiny boy,
With hey, ho, the wind and the rain,
A foolish thing was but a toy,
For the rain it raineth every day.
But when I came to man's estate,
With hey, ho, etc.
'Gainst knaves and thieves men shut their gate,
For the rain, etc.
But when I came, alas! to wive,
With hey, ho, etc.
By swaggering could I never thrive,
For the rain, etc.
But when I came unto my beds,
With hey, ho, etc.
With toss-pots still had drunken heads,
For the rain, etc.
A great while ago the world begun,
With hey, ho, etc.
But that's all one, our play is done,
And we'll strive to please you every day.
